Record date: 2092-09-18
EDVISIT^14477347^Bennett, Nancy^09/20/92^NOE, NATALEY KINSLEE
CHIEF COMPLAINT: Dizzy.
I confirm that I have seen and evaluated this patient, reviewed
the resident's documentation, and discussed the evaluation, plan
of care, and disposition with the patient.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a 74-year-old woman with a
history of diabetes and hypertension who for the last 24 hours
really has had trouble getting out of bed. She started feeling
dizzy having difficulty with moving and fatigue, never really
felt like this before. She does feel a little bit dizzy when she
stands up and went to North Iowa Oral Surgery Center where
they discovered her to be in heart block and sent her to us.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS. Negative for fever, chills, chest pain,
shortness of breath, and abdominal pain. She does admit to
several bug bites.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: History of polyarteritis nodosa 30 years
ago. She is non-insulin-dependent diabetes and hypertension.
MEDICINES, ALLERGIES, SOCIAL HISTORY, AND FAMILY HISTORY: As per
the chart.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: An obese woman awake, alert, and oriented.
She has a junctional rhythm in the 30s on the monitor with P
waves marching out as well but not in sequence with her QRS. Her
blood pressure is 150 systolic. She is awake and alert and her
oropharynx is normal. Neck is supple. Chest is clear. Cardiac
exam is bradycardic without murmur, rub, or gallop. Abdomen is
soft and nontender. Extremities: Without cyanosis, clubbing, or
edema. She does have an area of erythema in her mid back,
nontender, no central clearing.
EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT COURSE: The patient has an EKG that shows
AV dissociation with relatively narrow complex junctional escape
rhythm. Her chest x-ray is clean. The rest of her lab exam is
******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
by the EP Service and the plan is to take her to the Cath Lab for
a percutaneous transvenous pacer.
DIAGNOSIS: AV dissociation.
______________________________
NOE, NATALEY KINSLEE M.D.

**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2097-11-02
EDOBS^14477347^BENNETT, NANCY^11/02/97^OAKLEY, ALBERT
This is a shared visit with resident, Dr. Cantrell.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Briefly, this is a 79-year-old
female with a past history of insulin-dependent diabetes,
bronchitis, congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of
65%, COPD, and polyarteritis presenting here with some
generalized weakness since yesterday. She has no focal deficits.
She had no fall, no fevers, no chest pain, no shortness of
breath, no abdominal pain, no nausea, no vomiting, and no
diarrhea. She is able to ambulate with a walker. She denies
headache. She was feeling well until yesterday. She had no
recent medication changes. She has chronic lower extremity
edema, left greater than right. She has stable 2-pillow
orthopnea. She is followed by Dr. Whitman of Cardiology. She
takes Lasix 80 mg twice daily among other medications and the
status was stable. She had a normal cardiac stress test
approximately 4 months ago.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: She presents with a heart rate of 84,
respiratory rate of 16, blood pressure initially of 220/90,
systolic pressure decreased to 175 without treatment shortly
after arrival, and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air with
temperature of 98.5. She is awake and alert. She is in no acute
distress. She has moist mucous membranes. Her neck is supple
with full range of motion. She has mild left-sided facial droop,
which she states is old. She has clear and equal breath sounds
bilaterally and no respiratory distress. Heart is regular
without murmurs. She has soft, nontender belly. She has
asymmetric lower extremity edema with 2-3+ pitting edema to the
left and 1+ pitting edema to the right, which she states is
chronic and unchanged from baseline. She has 5/5 strength
throughout. She has no pronator drift. She is able to ambulate
with a walker.
LABORATORY DATA: Basic laboratory testing shows an unremarkable
CBC and Chem-7. A set of cardiac marker shows a troponin of
0.06, which is decreased from her most recent baseline, which has
been elevated over the past several months. Her BNP was 112.
Her urinalysis was unremarkable. Her EKG was a paced rhythm.
Chest x-ray was unremarkable.
EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT COURSE: The patient was discussed with Dr.
Whitman who recommended the patient be admitted to the
Observation Unit for another set of cardiac markers to ____
troponin as well as observation. He will see the patient in the
morning. If the patient's ____ set of cardiac markers are not
increasing and she feels well enough to go home, she will likely
be discharged after Dr. Whitman sees her and makes any
medication adjustments that are necessary.
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS: Hypertension.
SECONDARY DIAGNOSIS: Generalized weakness.
DISPOSITION: Observation Unit.
______________________________
OAKLEY, ALBERT M.D.
